item.name: Acquire
item.comment: [b]In the garage.[/b]

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
Age of Conan: The Strategy Board Game
item.comment:
I did not give much credit for this game when I first played it, but left the table intrigued and with the feeling it had a lot more to deliver.
Sure the crowning Conan mechanic is a downer as it can definitely break the game. But with a minor adjustment (we play that majorities on tokens are scored by every player) this game becomes a little gem.
The game beginning is slow paced, but it simulates in a very interesting way the expansion of the kingdoms. Fighting the provinces for domination forces you to make important decisions and to balance when to push your luck and try to score those points as sooner as possible.
When the expansionism is over, it is time to decide who’s a threat and, thus, where the next attacks will have to take place. Do not get diverged by the battles against the board. After that, the game becomes very confrontational. Combat being enhanced with the cards grants an intriguing balance between tactics and strategy.
In spite of Conan not being the central character of this game and just a mere coadjutant, Age of Conan provides an immersive playing experience sewing up lots of different mechanics.
Yes maybe it takes 1 hour longer than it should, but I don’t care. Fate dice add unexpected twists on play and one have to be very clever as to managing to see that no always the obvious choice is the best. Also, competing for tokens majority obliges players to pay close attention to other players’ turns, which is a nice artifice to try and keep balance of the game without the need of some serious ganging up.
All in all, with the abovementioned house rule, the somewhat mediocre crude stone becomes a well-polished gem. All matches I have played were extremely tight and at least 3 of the players had clear conditions to winning.
If you have the opportunity, grab this one. You won’t regret.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
Arte Moderna
item.comment: I managed to find a sealed copy of the rare Brazilian edition. Such a great game! One of Knizia's master piece, IMHO.

item.name: Bamboleo
item.comment:
This game is awesome! BUT only if you’re playing it for the 1st or 2nd time, when there still some uncertainty and tension of whether the plate will balance and how on Earth is that possible. After that, matches become very predictable and not surprise at all. This drives away all the fun of the game - the tension.
Don’t buy this one. Play a friend's copy. After 2 or 3 plays, you'll get everything the game has to offer. If you want a similar (but great) game, go for Villa Palletti.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: Works great as a party game without expansions. With the expansions... Well, let's just say I'd rather play something else.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment: Want an intrigue fan game? Get Saboteur. BSG drags. I get why fan of the series love it, as it is highly thematic. As I am not one of them, I prefer Saboteur much much better! Same feel. Quick and fun play.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b] - I have 2 copies. ;)

item.name: City of Horror
item.comment:
Great theme implementation!
This one really feels like a zombie holocaust. People dying all the time, hordes roaming from place to place. Backstabbing for survival. Goods shortage. Shifts of power...
However, it feels a little bit too repetitive. The good thing is that the game's got only 4 turns, which is just about time to keep things interesting and not tiresome.
Recomended!
BTW, I am one step away frmo saying that this is the best zombie game I've played.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
Dixit Odyssey
item.comment:
The game is still good, but the 12 players cause it to drag. What was meant to fluid and fun, becomes bumpy and annoying.
I would buy only for the new cards for variation (even though I think Dixit 1 + 2 are good enough for that). But even the thought of playing it with 12 people is forbbiden to me
item.wishlistcomment: Worse illustrations if compared to Dixit 1 and 2. Number of players increase is terrible. It just not seem to be worth it.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Conquest of Nerath Board Game
Elasund: The First City
item.comment:
The second game of the Adventure Catan serie. Interestingly, this one felt a little more dependent on the dice rolls to me, yet more strategic. I know this sounds contradictory, but I think that the placement of permits and the influence cards add a lot to the game in the sense of countering ‘screwage’ (and screwing) other players.
Regarding the random element of the dice, I must say that rolling a 7 feels much less prejudicial than in Settlers of Catan. The right numbers not coming up on the couple first turns can be quite slowing - and very likely to put some other players in advantage. This is less present in Catan as it is mitigated by the possibility of trading. Also, the mechanic helps very little in balancing the game, trying to hold the player who’s in lead. I believe that the robbers are much more efficient at that.
I would risk saying that this is more unbalanced than it’s older brother. Nevertheless, I believe it manages to be more strategic due to the already mentioned permits allocation.
As to each of them I think is better, I’d say it still a tie and will depend on the mood. Catan is much more lighthearted while Elasund provides a more intense gaming experience.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro
Horus Heresy
item.comment: I love the setting. I love the depth of the game. I love the theme and how great it depicts the novel. I'm not sure about the card combat system, but the game is very elegant over all. I like it a lot, but its playing and setup time makes it hard for it to hit the table oftenly. I say it's availbale for trading, but most of the times I do not know if I'd really let go of it.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: Mamma Mia!
item.comment: In the garage

item.name: Mehinaku
item.comment: Way too repetitive to my taste.

item.name: Monster Mayhem
item.comment: My first "modern" board game. Fun, but too random/party-like. Worked great at first, but my preference on mechanics/design started to change and I let this one go. I traded it for Settlers of Catan, if I'm no mistaken.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: In the garage

item.name: Munchkin 3: Clerical Errors
item.comment: In the garage

item.name: Netrunner
item.comment: In the garage

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
Pandemic
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: I can get the same amount of fun with little tin caps and some dug hole-ways on dirt/sand - and still nostagially recall my childhood. But the game itself is good, I just do not think it's worth its price.

item.name: Polarity
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment:
Only 2 plays so far (which is very little), but I'm failing to see the balance problems people are babbling about.
It is a simples game and it does seem a little raw still. However, it's got an amazing production value and plays bolt fast.
I have read about the variants* the designers suggested and they seem to add a lot to the game. I'm planning on testing them soon.
*Variants: - Instead of scoring the creature and moving it to the used pile, keep it and do not score. - You may capture up to 2 dice from the wilds on your turn (as long as you can pay for both, obviously). - Dragon grants only 3 glory points (this one is a most in my opinion).
Veredict: not a great game, but a very pleasant one. I'll hardly refuse to play it. I was very concerned about this one, but it delivered more than I expected (yet less than I ideally think it ought to).

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: Each player takes the role of a dwarf digging for gold. There might be saboteurs in the group, trying to prevent the "good-dwarves" from reaching the gold (the roles are hidden). Excelent filler/party game. Lots of finger pointing and laughs. Not that fun with smaller groups (2 - 4), though.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment:
Fun little cooperative. Highly thematic and great interaction among hero players.
I played just one match, but I must say it felt a little too easy. More experienced players argued that it was due to the group sinergy. I have to play a few more times to make sure.

item.name: The Settlers of Catan
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b] - I have 2 copies. ;)

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: Snow Tails: The Leap of Death
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment:
I can't stand this game any more. It annoys me. Gameplay is way too fiddly regardless of the game having so few components. Rules are obscure. You struggle to understand what is what. Facing, corridor, range, clearing a room, travelling. Nothing makes sense. You do not get the spacial feeling required for a game to seem claustrophobic at all!
Seriously. I won't be playing this game ever again!

item.name: Spartacus: A Game of Blood & Treachery
StarCraft: The Board Game – Brood War Expansion
The Three Musketeers: The Queen's Pendants
Tobago
item.comment:
[b]In the Garage[/b]
Traded for a copy of Settlers of America.

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment:
Silly. But fun as hell (supposing hell = loads of fun). Warning!! This one is highly adictive (think of crokinole). Do not buy this if you want your friends to keep play other games with you.
Side note: I recently took this one with me to a small friends convention. I had never heard so much cheering in one table. Grab this if you ever have the chance!

item.name: UR
item.comment:
Nice little abstract, yet with a present theme. Plays relatively quick, but it is certainly AP-prone. The mechanics of role selection integrated with the board disposition and actions availability are very clever.
I would probably not buy this one, but I most certainly will never refuse a game.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: [b]In the garage[/b]

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Adventure Game
Yoté
item.comment: Traded for Pücnt.

item.name: Zombicide
item.comment:
You probably heard that before, but this game is broken with 6 players. Way too easy for the survivors. However, the atmosphere of the game is great!
Wouldn't play it again with 6p, but I'm very curious to see how it goes with 4 players.
